tit.e: Gunchujo (requests for recognition of superior military valor)
Gunchujo (requests for recognition of superior military valor)
tit.cmt: タイトルなので、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 軍忠状（ぐんちゅうじょう）とは、中世日本において、参陣や軍功などを証する書類。
sen.e: Gunchujo (requests for recognition of superior military valor) refers to a document that proved a participation in a war and military exploit in medieval Japan.
Gunchujo are documents that proved participation in battles and other military exploits in medieval Japan.
Gunchujo were documents that proved participation in battles and other military exploits in medieval Japan.

sen.j: 中世日本において武士同士の主従関係は、御恩と奉公により成り立っていた。
sen.e: The relationship between the lord and vassal in medieval Japan is based on favor and service.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The relationship between lord and vassal in medieval Japan was based on favor and service.
The relationship between lord and vassal in medieval Japan was based on favor and service.

sen.j: 主人の軍事行動に当たり家来が手勢を引き連れ参陣し、又は戦場において軍功を挙げた場合（奉公）、主人はこれに対し、その「参陣」「軍功」が単なる私闘・私戦ではなく正当性のある「公戦」におけるものだと認定し、御恩と奉公御恩したり、新領地を恩賞として与えたり（御恩と奉公御恩）すべきものとされていた。
sen.e: When vassals participated in their lord's military action with their own forces/soldiers or showed their military exploit in the battlefields (contribute their serve), the lords were in return required to recognize the vassals' "participation" and "military exploit" for not their own private battle or war but a legitimate "official battle" in order to grant them favor, compensation for service, or new territory land as a reward (grant favor and compensation for service).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When vassals participated in military action initiated by their lord with their own soldiers or showed their military exploits on the battlefield (contributing service), the lords were in return required to recognize the vassals' "participation" and "military exploits" not for their own private battle or war but for a legitimate "official battle" in order that they be granted favor and compensated for their service, or receive new territory as a reward (the granting of favor and compensation for service).

When vassals participated in military action initiated by their lord with their own soldiers or showed their military exploits on the battlefield (contributing service), the lords were in return required to recognize 'participation' and 'military exploits' of the vassals not for their own private battle or war but for a legitimate 'official battle' in order that they be granted favor and compensated for their service, or receive new territory as a reward (the granting of favor and compensation for service).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えたりしました。

sen.j: そのため、後日の恩賞のため、参陣や軍功の事実を証する必要が生じた。
sen.e: Therefore a participation in a war or military exploit had to be proven for later rewards.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Therefore participation in war or military exploits had to be proven for later rewards.
Therefore participation in war or military exploits had to be proven for later rewards.

sen.j: かかる文書が主人名にて発給されることになった。
sen.e: This is because such a document began to be issued under the name of the lord.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: For this reason such documents began to be issued under the name of the lord.
For this reason such documents began to be issued under the name of the lord.

sen.j: 文書の様式は、まず文書先頭に自分の名前を書き、以下に軍忠の具体的事実を書くことを宣言する（「誰々申軍忠事」という文言になることが多い）。
sen.e: The document was written according to the following format; the vassal's name came first and then it stated the detailed fact of his superior military valorin (often with words: "I report our superior military valor.")

Such documents were written according to the following format; the vassal's name came first and then details regarding the facts of the vassal's superior military valor were stated (often with the words: "I report our superior military valor.")

Such documents were written according to the following format; the vassal's name came first and then details regarding the facts of the vassal's superior military valor were stated (often with the words: 'I report our superior military valor.')
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 次に軍忠の具体的事実、例えば合戦への従軍・敵に与えた損害・自軍の損害といったことを書く。
sen.e: Next it stated further detailed facts of superior military valorin; e.g. in what war the vassal served, what damages it afflicted on the enemy, and what damages its forces suffered.
Next came further details about the war or battle in which the vassal served, what damage was afflicted on the enemy, and what damage its own forces suffered.
Next came further details about the war or battle in which the vassal served, what damage was afflicted on the enemy, and what damage its own forces suffered.

sen.j: さらに同所で戦った武将の名前を挙げて、自身の軍忠の証明とする（具体的に名前を出さない場合もあり）。
sen.e: Furthermore it listed the busho (Japanese military commanders) with whom the valloin fought at the battlefield to prove his superior military valor.
It also listed the busho (Japanese military commanders) with whom the vassal fought on the battlefield, in order to prove his superior military valor.
It also listed the busho (Japanese military commanders) with whom the vassal fought on the battlefield, in order to prove his superior military valor (the name of busho were sometimes not listed).

sen.j: そして最後に「軍忠認定の証判を賜り、後日（の恩賞の）証拠としたい」といった旨の文言（文言は各文書で微妙に異なる）を記した。
sen.e: In the end it wrote the following words: "I would like my superior military valor to be recognized as the evidence for future (rewards)," (although the wording slightly differs from document to document).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: At the end the words "I would like my superior military valor to be recognized as evidence for future (rewards)" were written, although the wording differs slightly from document to document.
At the end the words 'I would like my superior military valor to be recognized as evidence for future (rewards)' were written, although the wording differs slightly from document to document.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 「以此旨可有御披露候」と文章を結ぶ。
sen.e: The document ended with words: "I hope that will be granted. "
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The document ended with the words: "I hope that this will be granted".
The document ended with the words: 'I hope that this will be granted.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 宛所は「進上 御奉行所」と書かれることが殆どである。
sen.e: In may cases, it was addressed: "To obugyosho (expression of a magistrate's office with respect)."
In many cases, it was addressed "To obugyosho (an expression of respect relating to a magistrate's office)".
In many cases, it was addressed 'To obugyosho (an expression of respect relating to a magistrate's office).'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: こうして軍勢の統括者に提出された軍忠状は、内容に問題が無ければ、文書末尾（先頭の場合もあり）にその統括者の証判（花押）と文書を一読し承諾した旨（「一見了」「承了」「無相違」などの文言）が書かれて効力が発生する。
sen.e: When the Gunchujo was submitted to the administrator of the troop and certified to be true, the document took effect with a approval mark of the administrator (Kao (written seal mark)) at the end of the document (or the head in some cases) and with words that I looked through it and agreed that it was not different from the fact (using words in Japanese such as "一見了," "承了," and "無相違").

When the Gunchujo was submitted to the administrator of the troops and certified to be true, the document took effect with the addition of the approval mark of the administrator (Kao, or written seal mark) at the end of the document (or the head in some cases) and with words along the lines of "I looked through the above and agree that it does not differ from the facts (using words in Japanese such as "一見了," "承了," and "無相違").

When the Gunchujo was submitted to the administrator of the troops and certified to be true, the document took effect with the addition of the approval mark of the administrator (Kao [written seal mark]) at the end of the document (or the head in some cases) and with words along the lines of 'I looked through the above and agree that it does not differ from the facts.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変え、前出に合わせて漢字部分を削除しました。

sen.j: これとは異なり、主人側にて書類を起案・交付するケースもあるようである。
sen.e: Otherwise some lords may have prepared and issued such a document.
It appears that some lords may have prepared and issued similar documents themselves.
It appears that some lords may have prepared and issued similar documents themselves.
